title: Matty Longstaff scores on dream Premier League debut in victory over Manchester United
text:
Manchester United were courting Newcastle’s Sean Longstaff during the summer, but they will be adding the name of younger brother Matty to their shortlist after the Premier League debutant bossed this contest and smashed a deserved winning goal.

It was a bold call by Steve Bruce handing the 19-year-old only his second senior appearance — but no player had a greater impact on a Newcastle performance so unrecognisable from the toil of recent weeks.

Bruce needed a response from his players after their capitulation during last Sunday’s 5-0 defeat at Leicester - and he got one.

Matthew Longstaff kisses the Newcastle crest after scoring against Manchester United

The teenager hammers beyond David de Gea and into the net on his Premier League debut

Rather than sit back and hit Manchester United on the break - as Bruce had vowed to do after talking of his squad’s attacking limitations on Friday - they actually took the game to the visitors and were aggressive and on the front foot from the off.

And it was Matty Longstaff who set the tone more than any other. Paired with his older sibling in the centre of midfield, he added the energy and enthusiasm so lacking of late among his elder team-mates.

Even his brother was inspired after a difficult season to date and the Geordie duo out-fought and out-thought an opposition midfield of Fred and Scott McTominay.

The midfielder celebrates his winning goal on Tyneside in front of a 51,198 crowd

Bruce risked upsetting his players by making public his concerns about their ability to attack before the game, but there was certainly no sulking here.

The inclusion of debutant Longstaff helped ensure that, for no academy graduate on the biggest day of his career is going to give anything less than 100 per cent.

That may sound like a simple requirement, but Newcastle’s effort levels at Leicester were some way below that mark.

Matty Longstaff added graft and craft to the side and capped what was already a man-of-the-match display by drilling home the game’s only goal on 72 minutes.

Matthew hits the crossbar during the first half at St James' Park with brother Sean watching on

Even in stoppage-time he had the awareness and maturity to hook one ball from danger and turn it into a defence-splitting pass for a team-mate to chase.

There was no hint of him tiring, either, as would have been forgiven on what should have been such a draining experience.

His smile was as wide as the Tyne on full-time, a grin rivalled by that of his brother.

The pair of them would have dreamt of such an outcome after learning they would be playing together on Saturday.

And so would Bruce. He needed this.
description: CRAIG HOPE AT ST JAMES' PARK: Manchester United were courting Newcastle's Sean Longstaff in the summer, but they will be adding the name of brother Matty to their shortlist.
